Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 10:22AM kimt wrote: I'm very interested in this question too - I am considering adding this but my doc said they haven't found any insurance company that will pay for ometa for reducing chance of recurrence, except in one case where the patient already had osteopenia.  We did a bone density to see if they can justify it to insurance based on my bone scan.  if not,t hey think they can get them to cover fosomax or one of those, based on the fact that I had my ovaries out.
Posts.Title: Zometa declined by regence - anyone appeal this? aprilgirl1 momto2angels

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 10:01AM kimt wrote: I also had genetic counseling - it was originally recommended to me by my surgeon because of my age, 41, at diagnosis.  But then the genetic counselor estimated my likelihood of being positive for bRCA1 or 2 to be low (no early breast or ovarian cancer in the family) and almost wasn't even going to do the test, but I wanted to know for others in the family and to help me make some other decisions.  I also knew there was probably a higher chance than she thought because of a small family with few women on the side that we thought the gene was coming from (I have no sisters, father has no sisters; his father died of prostate cancer in his 50s - that's where we think the gene is coming from).  Anyway, when they sent off the test, I was given a form that said the maximum I would have to pay would be $350, I think. that the testing lab would call me before proceeding if the insurance was not going to cover the rest, but I think my insurance covered everything.  The initial testing is expensive, $3500 or something, but then if you do test positive, you know exactly which gene variant you have, so if anyone else in the family wants to get tested, they only have to look for that same gene and it is cheaper.
Posts.Title: Genetics Counseling thepinkbirdie kaylaB

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 01:32PM kimt wrote: You certainly want to know if it will be laparoscopic or open (I had hysto-bso and my surgeon used a new procedure called SILS - Single incision laparoscopic surgery).  My recovery was VERY easy - had a routine appt with my onc a week later and they couldn't believe how good I looked.  And I have NO scar!  They went in through the belly button, just that one incision point - and took uterus out vaginally (hope that's not too much info!!) Also, that is a question - whether to take the uterus too, or just the ovaries.  My surgeon was okay with either, let me make the call.  Because I'm on tamox, I wanted the uterus out too b/c of the small chance of uterine cancer (that's rare, though - my onc says she's never seen it).
Posts.Title: Preperation for ooph consult....? lexislove kimt

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 02:14PM kimt wrote: I should say, my surgeon was also a gyn-onc.  And I hear you on the no more big surgeries!  I just found out I have gallstones - hoping i don't have to have my gallbladder out, although that is also laparoscopic, but still. not too psyched for more surgeries after I've already had 3 (lump, then ooph, then pbm because I'm BRCA2) and will have the exchange surgery to get my implants in July. Oh - I would second that on the stool softeners.  AND be sure to try to get up and move around, walk as much as possibly to disperse the gas after the laparoscopic surgery. I had no idea about that, but they pump you full of gas, which can be uncomfortable until it disperses.  I was feeling totally fine in a few days, though.
Posts.Title: Preperation for ooph consult....? lexislove kimt
